thread.title: 'Suspect is down': Cops recall closing in on Oregon school shooter
thread.title_full: 'Suspect is down': Cops recall closing in on Oregon school shooter | OregonLive.com

author: Rebecca Woolington | The Oregonian/OregonLive
title: 'Suspect is down': Cops recall closing in on Oregon school shooter
text:
Roseburg Detectives Joe Kaney and Todd Spingath pulled up to Umpqua Community College in an unmarked police car, with no lights or siren going.
Both men are veterans on the force and in the field. They've been in a shootout and spent time in the military. But last Thursday, they were wearing suits when they arrived at the school just outside their city. Neither had bullet-proof vests.
They happened to be among the closest to the school when they heard the call come over the police radio about 10:38 a.m:
"Somebody is outside one of the doors, shooting through the door ... we do have one female that has been shot at this time. We're still attempting to get further ...," the dispatcher said.
When the detectives arrived, they knew the shooter was in a Snyder Hall classroom. They knew he may have a long gun. And they knew about 35 people were scattered throughout the building with him.
They parked to the southeast of the hall at 10:44 a.m. They heard several shots as they approached.
The gunman was firing shots through the windows from inside the classroom.
They used their police car and other cars in the lot for cover and moved toward the shots. They saw the shooter, Christopher Harper-Mercer, standing right outside the classroom. They saw the muzzle on his 9 mm handgun flash.
***
Douglas County District Attorney Rick Wesenberg called them heroes. He said what they did next at the college saved lives.
Animated representation of police response to Umpqua Community College shooting This simple animation reconstructs the police response to the Umpqua Community College shooting, from the first 911 call at 10:38 a.m. to the report of "suspect down" at 10:48 a.m.
But Kaney and Spingath don't want to be called heroes, their chief said. They don't want the focus on them.
Nine people died inside Snyder Hall and another nine were injured.
Wesenberg released details of the encounter with the 26-year-old gunman during a news conference Wednesday at the Police Department in Roseburg. His account, along with police records and statements, provide some insight into what happened when the detectives headed into Oregon's deadliest mass shooting.
"I want everyone to know of the selfless acts of these officers in responding to the scene,'' Wesenberg said. "They had little regard for their own personal safety. They saved many lives that day in their heroic acts.''
***
"We're exchanging shots with him," Kaney radioed at 10:46 a.m.
The detectives fired three times from their .40-caliber hanguns at Harper-Mercer, striking him once in his right side. They were about 15 yards away. No words passed between the cops and Harper-Mercer.
The gunman retreated into the classroom. He walked up to the front and shot himself in the head.
The detectives approached the classroom from the east. State Police Sgt. Lynn Withers came from the west.
"Suspect is down," Withers told dispatch at 10:48 a.m.
Harper-Mercer was lying next to an assault rifle and a dark-colored flak jacket, lined with steel plates and packed with five magazines of ammunition. He had used a handgun in his rampage.
***
State police investigated Kaney and Spingath's actions that morning â€“ standard in police-involved shootings. District Attorney Wesenberg reviewed the report and determined that their gunfire was justified.
Wesenberg didn't specify how many rounds each detective fired or the number of shots Harper-Mercer fired at them. It's still unclear which detective shot Harper-Mercer.
Police didn't release further details about Harper-Mercer at their news conference. They focused solely on Kaney, a detective sergeant, and Spingath, a detective who works in Kaney's Criminal Investigation Division.
The detectives are trying to fall back into their routines, said Chief Jim Burge Jr. They don't want to be in the news.
"They feel they are only first responders who got there first and did a job they were trained and entrusted to do," he said.
They plan to return to duty this week.
